results.title: The Piano. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
A study of the expanding technique of pianoforte composition and playing during the 18th and 19th centuries, contrasting the delicacies of a Chopin Nocturne with the enormous complexities of Liszt, Schubert, Schumann, Brahms; many of the other great romantics are discussed and the modern school is touched on.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Organ. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Simon Preston, speaking from the console of the great Harrison organ in Westminster Abbey, tells of the history and construction of the instrument. He explains the simple theory of sound generation, the problems of providing constant air pressure, and the complexities of playing. Works by Mozart, Purcell and others are played.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: Orchestral percussion
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
James Blades accompanied by Joan Goossens explains the history of instruments of percussion and tells the story of their development from the striking of a hollow log or empty gourd to the percussion instruments of the modern orchestra.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Orchestra
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
The formation, selection and training of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain. Spotlights each section of the orchestra as they rehearse subtleties of intonation and phrasing until something like perfection is achieved. Then they perform Dvorak’s Carnival Overture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

results.title: Melodic percussion
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Films and Record Group and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
James Blades demonstrates the orchestral instruments of percussion - other than timpani - which are capable of melody as opposed to pure rhythm. the xylophone, vibraphone, marimba, glockenspiel, tubular bells and tuned gongs emerge in detail as vital parts of the modern orchestra and dance band.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Films and Record Group and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Industrial city
results.creator_credit: Hermann D. Tauchert and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Uses a case study of the industrial city of Detroit in order to present a view of the function of the industrial community in modern American society. Emphasises the fact that the future of a city depends on the education, training and ability of the people. Also discusses the automobile industry where 10,000 cars are produced per day at this time. Touches on the problems of traffic congestion, pollution, poverty and clime.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann D. Tauchert and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.description: Uses a case study of the industrial city of Detroit in order to present a view of the function of the industrial community in modern American society. results.title: The Indian in the cupboard
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, Frank Marshall, Jane Startz, Kathleen Kennedy, Kennedy/Marshall Company and Scholastic Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Lynne Reid Banks, ‘The Indian in the cupboard’ is a heartwarming adventure about nine year old Omri who magically brings his three-inch toy Indian Little Bear to life. Some of the scenes may not be suitable for very young children however the amazing adventures of these two friends is sure to delight.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Oz, Frank Marshall, Jane Startz, Kathleen Kennedy, Kennedy/Marshall Company and Scholastic Productions

results.title: The Immortal battalion = The Way ahead
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed, John Sutro, Norman Walker, G C F and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: Beginning as a British Army training film called “The New lot”, this film was then expanded into a feature length film written by Eric Ambler and Peter Ustinov, entitled “The Way ahead” for its British audience and re-edited into a slightly shorter film entitled “The Immortal battalion” for an American audience. Its basic concept is as a recruiting and training film for the British Army mixing training and combat footage with filmed sequences. The storyline is about a bunch of raw recruits from a variety of backgrounds who are finally welded into a unified and disciplined regimental unit ready for battle. Stars David Niven, Stanley Holloway, Peter Ustinov, Trevor Howard.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carol Reed, John Sutro, Norman Walker, G C F and Two Cities Films
results.description: Beginning as a British Army training film called “The New lot”, this film was then expanded into a feature length film written by Eric Ambler and Peter Ustinov, entitled “The Way ahead” for its British audience and re-edited into a slightly shorter film entitled “The Immortal battalion” for an American audience. Its basic concept is as a recruiting and training film for the British Army mixing training and combat footage with filmed sequences. The storyline is about a bunch of raw recruits from a variety of backgrounds who are finally welded into a unified and disciplined regimental unit ready for battle. Stars David Niven, Stanley Holloway, Peter Ustinov, Trevor Howard.

Its basic concept is as a recruiting and training film for the British Army mixing training and combat footage with filmed sequences. The storyline is about a bunch of raw recruits from a variety of backgrounds who are finally welded into a unified and disciplined regimental unit ready for battle. Stars David Niven, Stanley Holloway, Peter Ustinov, Trevor Howard.

results.title: In touch with the world
results.creator_credit: James B. Maas and David H. Gluck Productions and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human senses”.
Explains the functions of the human skin as a sense organ and the ability of the receptors to differentiate between at least five different kinds of sensations - touch, pressure, heat, cold and pain. Shows how the sense of touch has contributed to human development and adaptation of the human species to its environment.

results.title: The Image makers
results.creator_credit: Albert Kish, Adam Symansky, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary about the National Film Board of Canada made to commemorate the Board’s 40th anniversary in 1979. It is a montage representing the work of over 400 people whose dedicated efforts have garnered over 1800 international awards for the Board. Sometimes majestic, sometimes whimsical, the film is a revue of a nation’s sights and sounds.
